												A more up-to-date version of the CC classics.I will edit this review later, but first off I want to say something immediately.I see people claiming to be CC "fans", give it thumbs down, and post stuff like "you can't pause the game".Guess what, you can.. just hit the "pause" key on your keyboard. Now, that wasn't so hard, was it? And if you truly had played any of the predecessors, you'd realize that this version works just in the exact same way.By the way, you can press spacebar to activate range info (I have command influence range as standard). There's a comprehensive list of keybindings in the manual.Now, off to the game. CC is a top down, real-time action WWII strategy game, with roots as far back as 1996. CC is legendary for those beknownst to it. It continues the style of a few other games in the series with a grand-campaign-style strategic map. This strategic map will progress on a turn basis, with battles occuring after a movement phase. Battles will take place one by one, where two battlegroups clash on the grand map. Available at some points on the strategic map are also air support and artillery (to inderdict). When you battle, you will get loaded onto the proper map for the region you're in on the Strategic map, and the real-time action starts. The battles are realistic and intricate, with morale, cover, angle of attack, suppression, ammunition and range all being important factors to the outcome.Of course, you can scale the difficulty yourself, do skirmishes instead of a grand campaign, and set up your own battles, or even campaign if I recall correctly. Last time I checked there was also a functional multiplayer. And I guess this would be really fun to play with (against) friends.As for the price, I had to get it, not nescessarily because it's fairly priced (although I don't find it that steep) but because I want to support the making of anything CC, since the series are one of the few classics that stand out with great quality, which in my opinion should get all the support it could get. We have enough throwaway games today published by companies that care for nothing but money, with employees that have no passion for it whatsoever.

												I would hate for anyone new to pass this game series up just because of the mixed reviews.  I started playing with the original game by Atomic back in the '90s and worked my way up to CCIII which just completely blew my mind.   I then dropped out for about a decade and came back to the fold recently with this title and the remastered Cross of Iron.  These are amazing tactical games. If you are into World War 2 as a historical subject and are interested in small unit tactics and tactical combat, you will enjoy these games on some level.  My recommendation does come with a couple qualifications.  First, for series veterans, the newer games really do not do a lot different or new.  Playing these later day Close Combat games feels more like playing a heavily modded original, or remastered expansion pack.  The formula is the same, the limitations are the same, it's all just a little bit smoother and prettier.   If you already have and enjoy other titles in the series and aren't especially interested in this conflict, it may not offer enough new content for you.Now, for the new players, I would say that these games are awesome and you may well enjoy them, but they are dated in a number of ways and they're by no means perfect simulations either.  If you're a casual gamer or someone looking for a more 'traditional' RTS experience or coming from sometihng like CoH, you may be frustrated with some of the game mechanics and the dated UI and graphics. That said, if you're someone with a serious interest in history or small unit tactics, this game might just hit what you're looking for.   If you enjoy other games like the Steel Panthers series or Combat Mission, there's probably something you'll enjoy here.  I certainly do not regret the purchase.

												Close Combat: Gateway to Caen is an excellent Close Combat game that details Operation Epsom, a British plan to flank German positions at Caen to basically create a short cut into the city, whilst at the same time taking down German defenders at the Odon river. Historically, it was a costly battle for both Axis and Allies, and technically the Allies won, as German defenders committed all of their armour to close the gap, essentially wasting their fuel and vehicles on re-establishing their positions on the river Odon after the initial British attack. The British, as said, paid a high price, as they were up against veteran armour 'fresh' from the eastern front, that chewed up British armour like nothing else. The battle could have gone either way, and so the 'what if' factor is perfect for a game where you can play both sides.Gateway to Caen takes some getting used to if you are a veteran of the CC series. Unit scale is back to somewhat smaller, and unit choices per battle when playing the grand campaign are somewhat more limited. This is by no means a bad thing as you are finally forced to truely consider what you field when. When playing the campaign, as troops grow tired you HAVE to rotate them out every so many battles, or they eventually panic/surrender, no matter what their quality.Units included in the game are, amongst others, 2nd & 12th SS Panzer ('Das Reich'& the infamous 'Hitlerjugend' fanatics), The Royal Scots Fusiliers, the 46th Highland infantry brigade, 9th RTR and 43rd Wessex Infantry division. The main campaign is pretty well balanced: Generally speaking the British forces outnumber the Germans with what they can field at any given time, but the Germans often outgun the British with their heavy armour and 88mm Flak batteries. German troops do consist mainly of 'ad hoc' defenders initially, making for a pretty steep start when playing Germans, despite the prepared positions and the big guns.On my YouTube channel, I dedicated a series to this game, playing the main campaign as the Germans, check it out here:

I recommend this game to anyone interested in World War 2 gaming and the Close Combat series in general.

												Last chapter in a 15yr journey. One which has inspired a great degree of loyalty and an inordinate amount of frustration in the slightly masochistic fan base. Despite various moves between publishers not much has changed. Incremental improvements in cosmetics have only served to cover the significant failings of the game. Issues which were complained of long and hard by the fan base a decade ago continue to collect under the increasing undulations of the Slitherine rug: Path finding resides in the domain of a game of blind mans bluff. Units fumble around unable to distinguish between a straight line and a circle. Frequently regarding enemy LOS (Line of Sight) much as a moth regards a light source;The AI displays a form of paralysis, possibly catatonia. Slightly more advantageous to defence than attack. Awaiting an advance from the AI can resemble watching paint dry (Don't switch the scenario timer off). When it does chose to move, it’s invariably a drip feed;LOS could be redefined as LOP(Line of Possibility). Set up a units field of fire at the start only to discover a tank in midrange has become a form of terrestrial submarine;Campaigns can become highly repetitive. Grinding over the same maps repeatedly. An exercise in patience and/or frustration;Pricing. A world unto themselves. Cited by customers and reviewers consistently as overpriced for the age of the game, game engine and the lack of development. Slitherine persist with the tried and tested fingers in ears....’la,la,la...’.How is this a positive review? Short of hitting the invisible ‘middle button’, it’s a pretty good multiplayer experience. Even single player has it’s moments and manages to show glimpses of what the game could have been if it had been given the same investment Slitherine demand of it’s audience.If you have a history of war gaming you’ll no doubt suffer through the shortcomings and gain a modicum of enjoyment. More so if you can engage the multiplayer. If you are a casual visitor to war gaming don’t damage a possible future in the area by choosing this as your initiation.Whatever your interest....wait for a sale. Slitherine have their own around Christmas, and Steam offers their titles at a reasonable price about every six months.Lastly, there is a new Close Combat title soon to be released. ‘Close Combat: The Bloody First’. A new game engine and an opportunity for Slitherine/Matrix to redress the issues which have accompanied the series. If you are new to the series...I’d wait.And, probably pay the ransom ;)GM

												Wow, what a blast from the past! I used to play this game religiously when it was first released almost 20 years ago. Having it remastered and re-released for modern operating systems is, quite literally, a dream come true. I thought I'd never play a Close Combat game again. Despite the decades old, hand-drawn graphics -- which are a totally charming aspect anyway -- this is another Close Combat which sticks to the forumla and delivers an unmatched tactical experience. This game really brings home what it is to command a Company in combat. Every last detail of your soldiers is considered, their ammunition, fatigue, morale, suppression, accuracy, and courage or cowadice. You will revel in their success and you will cringe at their destruction. You alone are responsible for both. Notable improvements include revamped explosion graphics, the addition of waypoints to movement orders, and, finally, persistent tracking of individual soldiers between battles. Your men maintain their kills, awards, and performance. A word of warning, don't become attached to a particular Platoon, because there is nothing more gut-wrenching than watching a decorated, three battle veteran, finally succumb to his own bravery. My rating: 9/10. I cannot recommend this game enough. I am a biased reviewer, that's for sure, and if you're new to the series then perhaps you'd want to wait for the price to drop. However, if you're looking for a visceral, challenging, and realistic tactical strategy game, then you cannot go past Close Combat. There is literally nothing like this on the market.

												The graphics may be straight out of '95, but the slow-paced, platoon-sized and  fairly realistic combat is what I enjoy when it comes to strategy games.In combat, it comes down to controlling victory points across the map, at your disposal you will for the most part have two infantry platoons and one support-platoon. The latter one including vehicles, armor and static weapons. The combat itself comes down to suppressing the enemy troops as you attempt to outflank them and using your support-platoon to deal with entrenched infantry and enemy armor. Your units may refuse to follow your orders, act on their iniative and even surrender if the situation is dire. Each side has a certain morale depending on previous battles and current events on the battlefield, if this drops to zero or you lost all victory points, you will loose the battle.There's single battles, operations and campaigns in the singleplayer. In the latter two, you control serveral companies that you move in a turnbased-fashion around a larger map. Battles will most likely be fought on the same map serveral times during these, where you start off around  the victory points you control, a nice feature being that wrecks, craters and ruined buildings remain throughout the entire operation or campaign.The negative aspects are that it does a poor job at explaining some of it's mechanics and evidently the previously mentioned graphics from 1995. And considering how little has changed since the previous release of "Panthers in the Fog", it's not really worth the current asking price. But if it's on sale, I would strongly reccomend it.

												I didn't know what to expect, but upon firing the game up, this is the classic Close Combat experience that I remember from over a decade ago.Imagine a more "thinkier" version of Company of Heroes.  If you want a slower paced, more strategic RTS experience, then this game is right up your alley.  On the battlefield, position, moral, ammo, physical conditioning, line of sight, and many other issues come into play as you decide where to place and move your soldiers.  Battles are slow, gripping affairs, as every single soldier is valuable and the fog of war is dense.  Indeed, it is very possible for matches to end in stalemates, as both sides decide that it is completely unsafe to advance into the open killing fields.On the campaign map, you have to decide where to move troops and where to place support options.  Having artillery ready on a map can mean the difference between victory and defeat, but if you deploy your options in the wrong sectors, you may find that your lines and resources will be stretched completely thin.It's very old fashioned, for sure, and it doesn't look great compared to Company of Heroes or any of the other modern RTSes.  But if you're willing to forgive that much, then you're in for a great war game experience.

My biggest concern is that, even as a fan of the original series, this company (Slitherine) is attempting to call this a new game... it's not.It had been mentioned in another review, but it is also quite apparent when playing, that it is the same engine, the same assets (although 32bit, which i think is a lie because it looks the same as the 15 year old CC:III), and the same artwork. It has been a while since I played CC:IV Invasion Normandy, but I recall that the maps in this game are taken from CC:IV. Normally I wouldnt have a problem with all that I mentioned above, afterall I looked at this game from the perspective of being an update/remake of a game that I loved. The problem is; they didn't do a damn thing to update it. NOTHING. The strategic map was taken from the older games. The RPG-ish elements of having command and soldiers throughout multiple battles/campaigns was taken from the older games. Absolutely nothing has been done to this game to separate it from the old games, which again, being a huge fan of the old games would normally be OK. Except for one huge thing...THE PRICE. Now being that I paid $10 for this in a humble bundle, I don't feel like I have been swindled. But I can sympathize with those that paid $40.00 for this game thinking that it was some new iteration of the CC series.This may be hyperbolic, but, Slytherine should be ashamed of themselves. I can only imagine how many people have been tricked into buying this game at the price of $40.00. $40.00!!!! Let that sink in. I will wrap this up by saying this... I paid $10 and sent almost all of the $10 to charity. I gave slitherine one cent. One cent is about how much effort was put into this game.That may sound really harsh, but again, I am a huge fan of this series and I am going to continue playing this game, but not without constantly feeling lucky that I didn't pay full price for it.

												I am really disappointed with this game.  It is a good idea but poorly executed.  I don't mind the 2D look but there needs to be more player aids to deal with it.  Often you cannot tell what unit has Line of Sight or what obstacles block LoS. The third issue is you cannot rebind the hot-keys.  While there isn't that many, they aren't that logical.  The alternative is to find the unit, right click it and find the command you want.  Fourth is the inability to customize squads.  This makes it extremely difficult to play axis because there is almost no way to defeat Churchill tanks in the 6-8 battles I played.  I have tried to ambush it in side but that didn't work either.  This inability to deal with heavy armor is compounded by the fact that you cannot retreat(or I haven't figured it out).  Lastly, there is no tutorials when there is clearly a button for them(it is greyed out).  It would of helped in order to deal with the controls.  Overall, this game feels half finished and the price(while on sale) was not worth it.

												One of the best real time strategy games that gives realistic company sized WW2 battles, modeling supplies, psycology and PTSD, this game series has been a solid entry since 1996. Vehicle drivers are terrible and so you will need to micromanage the drivers to keep them on the path. this may be the weakest part of the entire series.Still, if you can get past that then you will find the best Company sized military strategy game available, far exceeding the modern AAA such as company of hero's. it doesnt have there AAA looks, but its much more realistic psycology model and battlefield tactics makes this an infnatry commanders dream training tool.

												I'd like to begin saying that I'm biased towards this series, seeing how I've played every installment since the first. To me this is the optimal WW2-tactical game. What got me to like this series was how it got you close to the action and provided you with an efficient interface to command your combating soldiers. To me every battle I've played has been a mini *insert-your-favorite-war-flick-here*. Before long the battlefield is scarred by explosions and fire, the dead and dying are piling at the victory points and you are sitting by the keyboard ruing for Fritz or Cambell who's lying in ambush trying to capture that Sherman/Tiger-tank off-guard.The strategy portion of the game is as it's been since it's inception and as always to me a distraction, I find the heart to be in the battles. Each battle can range from 30-60 minutes so set aside some time if you choose to play the campaign. The system is impeccable, with only minor changes here and there from the previous games, and as always a wonderful historical accuracy. The battles and missions who are just based on history are noted as such.The interface is the only main concern I have. But this may be because I'm so used to the bottom-centered interface after years of playing that I'm unable to get to grips with the changes. I haven't played so much yet so maybe after a couple of more hours I'll get a hold of the new setup.Every battle is a story and if you have the time to dedicate you'll not be sorry. This is if you have a little interest for military history and good strategy games, but who doesn't? Now I just hope they'll start porting the classics too, I'd like to play The Russian Front and Invasion Normandy again, this time with support for multiplayer via Steam. Get to it!

												It's good, but it's a little buggy on my usually stable rig. Gameplay is similar to A Bridge Too Far, the last Close Combat game I played, and this is a good thing. Really, this is what I like about these games - the realistic battles that require some degree of actual skill to succeed at.The map editor feels awkward compared to the older style, but seems like it allows much better campaigns to be developed once you get the swing of things. Infact, there is a whole new campaign design to it, albiet one I don't personally find overly interesting.Favorite new stuff: New additions such as long distance mortar and artillery support are kinda neat. There are lots of little tweaks and stuff to the same units, and a bunch of new ones. Quite a few UI updates.Least favorite new stuff: As I say, I'm not a fan of the new campaign setup beyond the above mentioned parts. I might just not be great at it, but it's really too restrictive to feel like a proper grand strategy element. It feels like you need to replicate the actual events of the battles depicted to actually succeed in most of the campaigns, which is not great when you're a pretty casual WWII history buff like me.Also, they seem to have removed the ability to see LOS during deployment, something I remember being in A Bridge Too Far, and really a ♥♥♥♥-er of many otherwise good plans. Perhaps it's a realism thing, but I think a real MG team would notice if they were setting up facing directly into a a slight bump that would completely block their line of sight.Summing it up, I am a  mixed on it because I think A Bridge Too Far does just as good a job of the parts that I enjoy. Maybe even does it a little better, really. If you somehow have a working copy of A Bridge Too Far, you might want to check out some gameplay videos of the grand strategic mode to see if it's your thing before dropping $40 on it.Dunno if it's worth $40 if you have a working copy of Bridge Too Far, but it's the game you expect, for sure.
